You should now contemplate that all conditioned things are mixed with various dharmas, without self, impermanent, and not abiding. This body has many immeasurable faults, just like water bubbles. Therefore, you should not weep now.
At that time, Pure Giving again addressed the Buddha, saying:
It is just as you have taught.
Although I know that the TathÄgata skillfully manifests entering nirvÄá¹‡a, I am still unable to avoid feeling grief and distress. But when I reflect on it, I feel joy.
The Buddha praised Pure Giving, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
You are able to know that the TathÄgata manifests the same as sentient beings, skillfully entering nirvÄá¹‡a.
Pure Giving!
You should now listen. Just as the sÄrasa birds all gather at Lake Anavatapta in the spring,
the buddhas are also like this, all coming to this place.
PÅ«rá¹‡a!
You should not now contemplate the buddhas' long life or short life. All dharmas are like illusory appearances. The TathÄgata, in the midst of this, with skillful means, is unattached and unstained.
Why is this?
It is because the dharmas of the buddhas are thus.
PÅ«rá¹‡a!
I now accept the offerings you present, in order to enable you to cross over birth and death and the various existences.
Those humans and devas who make their final offerings to me will all attain immovable karmic rewards and will always experience peace and happiness.
Why is this?
It is because I am a good field of merit for sentient beings.
If you wish to make offerings to sentient beings as a field of merit, quickly prepare your offerings and do not delay.
At that time, Subhadra, in order to liberate sentient beings, lowered his head, drank in the tears, and said to the Buddha:
Excellent, World-Honored One!
If I am able to be a field of blessings, then I will be able to understand the TathÄgata's nirvÄá¹‡a and non-nirvÄá¹‡a.
We Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas now have wisdom like mosquitoes and ants, and truly cannot measure the TathÄgata's nirvÄá¹‡a and non-nirvÄá¹‡a.
At that time, Subhadra and his relatives, with sorrowful cries and tears, surrounded the TathÄgata, burning incense, scattering flowers, and respectfully serving with all their heart.
He then followed MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« and left his seat to prepare the food.
Shortly after he left, the earth quaked in six ways, and so did the Brahma world.
There are two kinds of earthquakes, sometimes the earth moves, and sometimes the great earth moves.
A small quake is called an earth quake, and a great quake is called a great earth quake.
A small sound is called an earthquake, a loud sound is called a great earthquake.
An earthquake that moves only the earth is called an earthquake, an earthquake that moves mountains, rivers, trees, forests, and the great ocean is called a great earthquake.
An earthquake that moves in one direction is called an earthquake, an earthquake that moves in a circular motion is called a great earthquake.
An earthquake is called an earthquake, an earthquake that can move the minds of sentient beings when it moves is called a great earthquake.

When the Bodhisattva first descends from Tuá¹£ita Heaven to JambudvÄ«pa, it is called a great earthquake. When he is first born, leaves home, attains supreme perfect enlightenment, turns the wheel of the Dharma, and enters parinirvÄá¹‡a, it is called a great earthquake.
Today, the TathÄgata is about to enter nirvÄá¹‡a, and therefore this earth is greatly shaking.

At that time, the devas, nÄgas, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, kiá¹ƒnaras, mahoragas, humans, and non-humans, having heard these words, their body hairs all stood on end, and they wailed in unison, speaking a verse, saying:
We bow our heads to the Tamer, we now entreat you,
Do not leave and part from the human sage, forever without protection.
Now seeing the Buddha's nirvÄá¹‡a, we are drowning in the sea of suffering,
Grieving and sorrowful, like a calf losing its mother.
Poor and without protection, like a sick person in distress,
Without a doctor, following one's own mind, eating what should not be eaten.
Sentient beings' affliction of illness, always harmed by various views,
Far from the Dharma doctor, taking poisonous medicine of wrong views,
Therefore, the World-Honored Buddha should not abandon us.
Just as a country without a ruler, the people all starve,
We are also like this, losing the shade and the taste of the Dharma.
Now hearing of the Buddha's nirvana, our minds are confused and disordered,
Just like the great earth moving, confused and lost in all directions.
The Great Sage entering nirvana, the Buddha-sun falling to the ground,
The Dharma-water all dried up, we will certainly die,
The TathÄgata's parinirvÄá¹‡a, sentient beings are extremely miserable,
Like an elder's son, newly losing his parents.
If the TathÄgata enters nirvana and does not return,
We and all sentient beings will have no savior.
The TathÄgata entering nirvana, even down to the animals,
All are sorrowful and fearful, the suffering and distress burning their minds.
How can we not be sorrowful today?
The TathÄgata sees and abandons us, as if discarding spittle.
Just as when the sun first rises, its light is extremely bright,
It can illuminate itself, and also eliminate all darkness.
The TathÄgata's light of spiritual powers can remove our suffering and distress,
Abiding in the great assembly, like Mount Sumeru.
World-Honored One!

It is like a king who begets sons, their appearance upright, always loved and remembered in his heart. He first teaches them skills, making them all proficient, and then entrusts them to the executioner to be killed.
World-Honored One!
We are now the Dharma King's sons, having received the Buddha's teachings and attained right view. We pray that you will not abandon us;
If you abandon us, it will be the same as abandoning the prince.
We only pray that you will remain for a long time and not enter nirvÄá¹‡a.
World-Honored One!
It is like a person who has studied all the treatises but then becomes afraid of them.
The TathÄgata is also like this. He has penetrated all dharmas, but he is still afraid of all dharmas.
If the TathÄgata were to remain in the world for a long time, expounding the taste of the nectar and satisfying everyone, then beings would not be afraid of falling into hell.
World-Honored One!
It is like a person who first learns to work and is arrested by the authorities and imprisoned.
Someone asks him:
What are you experiencing?
He replies:
I am now experiencing great suffering. If I can escape, then I will attain peace and happiness.

The World-Honored One is also like this. For our sake, you have cultivated ascetic practices. We have not yet escaped the suffering and distress of birth and death. How can the TathÄgata attain peace and happiness?
World-Honored One!
It is like a master physician who is skilled in prescriptions and medicines. He exclusively teaches the secret methods to his son and does not teach them to others who come to study.
The TathÄgata is also like this. He alone uses the profound and secret treasury to teach MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«, abandoning us and not looking upon us with compassion.
The TathÄgata should not be stingy with the Dharma, like that physician who only teaches his son and does not teach those who come from outside to study.
The reason that physician is unable to teach universally is because he cherishes victory and defeat and therefore has secrets.
The TathÄgata's mind will never have victory or defeat. Why is it like this? He does not teach.
We only wish that you will stay for a long time and not enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.
World-Honored One!
It is like an old, young, or sick person who leaves the good path and walks on a dangerous road. The road is dangerous and difficult, and they suffer much hardship.
There is another person who sees them and takes pity on them. They then show them a flat and good road.
World-Honored One!

I am also like this. The young refers to those whose Dharma body has not yet grown, the old refers to those with heavy afflictions, the sick refers to those who have not yet escaped birth and death, and the dangerous road refers to the twenty-five existences.
I only wish that the TathÄgata will guide us on the true path of immortality and remain in the world for a long time, not entering nirvÄá¹‡a.
At that time the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:
You bhiká¹£us, do not grieve and weep like ordinary people, gods, and others;
You should diligently make progress, focus your mind, and be mindful.
At that time the gods, asuras, and others, hearing what the Buddha said, stopped crying.
It was like when a person has buried their child and stops crying.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke this verse for the great assembly:
You should open your minds and not grieve too much;
The Dharma of the buddhas is all like this, so you should be silent.
Delight in the practice of non-negligence, guard the mind and be rightly mindful,
Far remove from all that is unlawful, comfort the mind and experience joyful happiness.
Furthermore, bhiká¹£us!
If there are any doubts, you should all ask now.

If it is empty or not empty, if it is permanent or impermanent, if it is suffering or not suffering, if it is a basis or not a basis, if it goes or does not go, if it is a refuge or not a refuge, if it is constant or not constant, if it is cut off or permanent, if it is a sentient being or not a sentient being, if it exists or does not exist, if it is real or not real, if it is true or not true, if it ceases or does not cease, if it is secret or not secret, if it is dual or non-dual, if there are doubts regarding such various dharmas, you should ask now, and I will explain them for you in accordance with the truth. I will also first expound the nectar for you, and then I will enter nirvÄá¹‡a.
Bhiká¹£us!

It is difficult for a Buddha to appear in the world, difficult to obtain a human body, difficult to encounter a Buddha and give rise to faith, difficult to endure what is difficult to endure, difficult to attain arhatship with perfect precepts and without deficiency, like seeking gold dust or an udumbara flower.
You bhiká¹£us!
It is difficult to obtain a human body free from the eight difficulties, and you should not let your encounter with me go to waste.

I have practiced various austerities in the past, and now I have attained such an unsurpassed skillful means. For your sake, I have abandoned my body, hands, feet, head, eyes, marrow, and brain for immeasurable eons. Therefore, you should not be negligent.
You bhiká¹£us!
How do you adorn the city of the true Dharma treasure, replete with various precious virtues, using precepts, concentration, and wisdom as your walls and moats?

You have now encountered this treasure city of the Buddha's teachings, and should not take these false and deceptive things, just as a caravan leader encountering a true treasure city, taking worthless pebbles and returning home.
You are also like this, encountering a treasure city, taking false and deceptive things.
You bhiká¹£us!
Do not give rise to contentment with a lesser mind.
Although you have now gone forth, you do not yearn for this Great Vehicle.
You bhiká¹£us!
Although your bodies wear the dyed robes of the renunciant, your minds are still not dyed with the pure Dharma of the Great Vehicle.
You bhiká¹£us!
Although you go begging for alms, passing through many places, you have never before begged for the Dharma food of the Great Vehicle.
You bhiká¹£us!
Although you shave your beards and hair, you have not yet used the true Dharma to eliminate the afflictions.
You bhiká¹£us!

I will now truly instruct you. I am now in the great assembly, the harmony of the TathÄgata's Dharma nature is true and unerring. Therefore, you should be diligent, focus your mind, be courageous and destroy the afflictions. After the sun of the wisdom of the ten powers has set, you will be covered by ignorance.
Bhiká¹£us!

Just as the great earth, mountains, and medicinal herbs are used by sentient beings, so is my Dharma. It gives rise to the wonderful and good nectar-like flavor of the Dharma, which is the good medicine for the various afflictions and illnesses of sentient beings.
I will now cause all sentient beings, as well as my disciples in the fourfold assembly, to all abide in the secret treasury. I will also abide therein and enter nirvÄá¹‡a.
What is called the secret treasury?
It is like the three dots of the letter i. If they are placed side by side, it does not form i. If they are placed vertically, it also does not form i;
It is like the three eyes on Mahesvara's face, which together form the letter i with three dots. If they are separate, they cannot form it either.
It is the same for me. The Dharma of liberation is not nirvana, the Tathagata's body is not nirvana, and Mahayana prajna is not nirvana. These three dharmas are different and also not nirvana.
I now abide in these three dharmas and for the sake of sentient beings, I call it entering nirvana, like the Chinese character i.

At that time, the bhikshus heard that the World-Honored Buddha was definitely going to enter nirvana. They all became sorrowful, their body hairs stood on end, tears filled their eyes, they bowed at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him countless times, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
You have eloquently explained impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self.
World-Honored One!
It is like how among all the tracks of beings, the elephant's track is supreme. The thought of impermanence is also like this. Among all thoughts, it is the foremost.
If one diligently cultivates and practices it, one can eliminate all desires of the desire realm, desires of the form and formless realms, ignorance, arrogance, and the notion of impermanence.
World-Honored One!
If the TathÄgata is free from the notion of impermanence, then he should not enter nirvÄá¹‡a now.
If he is not free from it, how can you say that cultivating the notion of impermanence eliminates desires of the three realms, ignorance, arrogance, and the notion of impermanence?
World-Honored One!
It is like a farmer who deeply plows the field in the autumn months, able to remove the weeds.
This notion of impermanence is also like this, able to eliminate all desires of the desire realm, desires of the form and formless realms, ignorance, arrogance, and the notion of impermanence.
World-Honored One!ğŸ”½It is like plowing fields, autumn plowing is the best.
Among all tracks, the elephant track is the best.
Among all notions, the notion of impermanence is the best.
World-Honored One!
It is like a king who, knowing his life is about to end, grants amnesty to the world, releasing all prisoners and captives, and then gives up his life.
The TathÄgata should now do the same, delivering all beings, freeing them from the bonds of ignorance and nescience, and only then enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.
We have not yet been delivered, so how can the TathÄgata abandon us and enter nirvÄá¹‡a?
World-Honored One!
It is like someone possessed by a ghost who encounters a good spell-master, who, by the power of the spell, is able to be cured.
The TathÄgata is also like this. For the Å›rÄvakas, he removes the ghost of nescience, enabling them to abide in the MahÄprajÃ±Ä, liberation, and other dharmas, like the Chinese character i.
World-Honored One!
It is like a fragrant elephant that is bound by people. Even if there is a good trainer, he cannot restrain it. The elephant breaks the ropes and chains and goes wherever it pleases.
I have not yet been liberated from the fifty-seven fetters of afflictions. How can the TathÄgata wish to abandon me and enter nirvÄá¹‡a?
World-Honored One!
It is like a person suffering from malaria who encounters a good doctor and is cured of their illness.

I am also like this, with many afflictions and the fever of wrong livelihood. Although I have encountered the TathÄgata, my illness has not yet been cured and I have not yet attained the unsurpassed peace and constant bliss.
How can the TathÄgata wish to abandon me and enter nirvÄá¹‡a?
World-Honored One!
It is like a drunkard who is not aware of himself and does not recognize his relatives, mothers, daughters, sisters, and so on. He is confused, lustful, speaks recklessly, and lies down in filth.

At that time, a good teacher gives him medicine to take. After taking it and vomiting the alcohol, he regains his memory. Feeling ashamed and deeply reproaching himself, he thinks, Alcohol is the root of all evil and unwholesomeness. If I can eliminate it, then I will be far from all offenses.
World-Honored One!

I am also like this. In the past, I have been revolving in birth and death, intoxicated by emotions and forms, craving the five desires, thinking of my mother as not my mother, thinking of my sister as not my sister, thinking of my daughter as not my daughter, giving rise to the thought of sentient beings where there are no sentient beings, and therefore revolving and experiencing the suffering of birth and death, like that drunk person lying in filth.

The TathÄgata should now bestow the Dharma medicine on me, causing me to vomit out the evil wine of afflictions, but I have not yet attained the mind of awakening. How can the TathÄgata be willing to abandon me and enter nirvÄá¹‡a?
World-Honored One!
It is like someone praising a plantain tree as having a solid core. There is no such thing.
World-Honored One!

Sentient beings are also like this. If one praises a self, a person, a sentient being, a life, one who is nurtured, one who perceives, one who acts, or one who receives, as being real, there is no such thing. We cultivate the view of no-self in this way.
World-Honored One!
It is like the dregs of a drink, no longer of any use;
this body is also like this, without self, without owner.
World-Honored One!
It is like a seven-leaf flower that has no fragrance;
this body is also like this, without self, without owner. We always cultivate the thought of no-self in this way.
As the Buddha has said:

'All dharmas are without self and what belongs to self. You bhiká¹£us should cultivate this. Having cultivated in this way, you will eliminate the conceit of self. Having left behind the conceit of self, you will then enter nirvÄá¹‡a.'
World-Honored One!
It is like a bird's tracks, appearing in the sky - this is impossible.
One who is able to cultivate the thought of no-self, yet has various views, this is also impossible.
At that time the World-Honored One praised the bhiká¹£us, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
You are well able to cultivate the thought of no-self.
Then the bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
We not only cultivate the notion of non-self, but also cultivate other notions, namely the notion of suffering, the notion of impermanence, and the notion of non-self.
World-Honored One!
It is like a drunk person whose mind is dizzy and sees all mountains, rivers, rocks, trees, palaces, houses, the sun, moon, and stars all spinning.
World-Honored One!

If there are those who do not cultivate the notion of suffering, impermanence, non-self, and so forth, such people are not called sages, are very negligent, and transmigrate in the cycle of birth and death.
World-Honored One!
For this reason, we skillfully cultivate these various notions.
At that time, the Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Listen carefully, listen carefully.
The drunkard analogy you just cited only understands the words but does not grasp their meaning.
What is the meaning?
It is like that drunk person who sees the sun and moon above, which are actually not spinning, but gives rise to the notion that they are spinning.

Sentient beings are also like this. They are covered by afflictions and ignorance, giving rise to inverted thoughts. They think the non-self is the self, the impermanent is permanent, the impure is pure, and suffering is happiness. Because they are covered by afflictions,
although they give rise to these thoughts, they do not understand their meaning, just like that drunkard who thinks he is turning when he is not turning.
The self is the meaning of Buddha, permanence is the meaning of Dharma body, bliss is the meaning of nirvana, and purity is the meaning of Dharma.
You bhiká¹£us!
How can you say that those who have the thought of self are arrogant, conceited, and transmigrate in birth and death?
If you say that you also cultivate the thoughts of impermanence, suffering, and non-self, these three kinds of cultivation have no true meaning.
I will now explain the supreme Dharma of the three cultivations. Those who consider suffering as happiness and happiness as suffering have the Dharma of inversion.
Those who consider the impermanent as permanent and the permanent as impermanent have the Dharma of inversion.
To think of non-self as self and self as non-self is an inverted dharma.
To think of the impure as pure and the pure as impure is an inverted dharma.
There are such four inverted dharmas. This person does not know how to correctly cultivate all dharmas.

You bhiká¹£us, in the midst of suffering dharmas you give rise to the notion of happiness, in the impermanent you give rise to the notion of permanence, in the non-self you give rise to the notion of self, and in the impure you give rise to the notion of purity.
The world also has permanence, happiness, self, and purity, and the supramundane also has permanence, happiness, self, and purity.
The worldly dharmas have the words but not the meaning, while the supramundane has both the words and the meaning.
Why is it so?
Because the worldly dharmas have four inversions, they do not know the meaning.
Why is it so?
There are inversions of thought, mind, and views.
Because of the three inversions, worldly people see suffering in happiness, impermanence in permanence, no-self in self, and impurity in purity. This is called inversion.
Because of inversion, worldly people know the letters but do not know the meaning.
What is the meaning?
The selfless is called birth and death, and the self is called the TathÄgata;
The impermanent is the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, and the permanent is the TathÄgata's Dharma body;
The suffering is all non-Buddhists, and the happiness is nirvÄá¹‡a;
The impure is conditioned phenomena, and the pure is the true Dharma possessed by buddhas and bodhisattvas;
This is called non-inversion.
Because of non-inversion, one knows the letters and knows the meaning.
If one wishes to be far removed from the four inversions, one should know such permanence, happiness, self, and purity.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, those who are free from the four inversions will then be able to understand permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
The TathÄgata is now forever free from the four inversions, and so has already understood permanence, bliss, self, and purity.

If he has already understood permanence, bliss, self, and purity, why does he not remain for an eon or half an eon to teach and guide us in being free from the four inversions, but instead abandons us and wishes to enter nirvÄá¹‡a?
If the TathÄgata would look upon us with concern and give us instructions, we would wholeheartedly accept and practice them.
If the TathÄgata enters nirvÄá¹‡a, how can we remain with this poisonous body and together abide in the practice of pure conduct?
We too will follow the World-Honored Buddha and enter nirvÄá¹‡a.
At that time the Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
You should not speak like this. All the unsurpassed true Dharma I possess I entrust to MahÄkÄÅ›yapa.
KÄÅ›yapa will be a great support for you, just as the TathÄgata is a support for sentient beings. MahÄkÄÅ›yapa will also be like this, serving as a support for you.
It is like a great king who has many subjects. When he goes on a tour of inspection, he entrusts all state affairs to his great ministers.
The TathÄgata is also like this. He entrusts all the true Dharma to MahÄkÄÅ›yapa.
You should know that the contemplation of impermanence and suffering that you have cultivated previously is not true.
It is like in the spring, when people go to a large pond to bathe, ride boats, and play. They lose a lapis lazuli jewel that sinks to the bottom of the deep water.

At that time, all the people enter the water together to search for the jewel. They compete to grab tiles, stones, grass, wood, sand, and gravel, each thinking they have obtained a lapis lazuli jewel. They joyfully bring it out, only to realize it is not real.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
At that time, the precious pearl was still in the water, and by the power of the pearl, the water became clear.
Then the great assembly saw the precious pearl still in the water below, just like looking up at the moon in the sky.
At that time, there was a wise person in the assembly who, with skillful means, slowly entered the water and obtained the pearl.

You bhiká¹£us should not practice impermanence, suffering, the idea of no-self, and the idea of impurity as true principles, like those people who took tiles, stones, grass, wood, sand, and gravel to be precious pearls.
You should skillfully learn skillful means, and in all places always cultivate the idea of self, the ideas of permanence, bliss, and purity.
You should also know that the characteristics of the four dharmas you have previously cultivated are all inverted.
If you want to truly cultivate all the ideas, it is like that wise person skillfully extracting the precious pearl, namely:
The idea of self, the ideas of permanence, bliss, and purity.
At that time the bhiká¹£us addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-honored One!
As the Buddha previously taught:
'All dharmas are without self. You should cultivate and study this!
Having cultivated and studied this, one will be free from the notion of self;
one who is free from the notion of self will be free from arrogance;
one who is free from arrogance will be able to enter nirvÄá¹‡a.'
What is the meaning of this?
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Excellent, excellent!
You are now able to ask about this meaning well, to cut off your own doubts.

It is like a king who is dull-witted and has little wisdom. There is a physician who is also stubborn by nature, and the king does not distinguish between them, but gives them both generous salaries. When treating illnesses, he only uses milk as medicine, and he also does not know the root causes of illnesses. Although he knows about milk medicine, he does not understand it well. Whether it is wind illness, cold illness, hot illness, or any other illness, he teaches everyone to drink milk.
This king does not distinguish between whether this physician knows the good and bad, right and wrong of milk.

There was also a skilled doctor who was well-versed in the eight kinds of medical techniques, good at curing various illnesses, and knowledgeable in medical prescriptions. He came from a distant place.
At that time, the old doctor did not seek advice or accept [the new doctor], but instead gave rise to a conceited and arrogant mind.
The skilled doctor then relied on [the old doctor] and requested to be his teacher, consulting and receiving the secret medical techniques. He said to the old doctor:
I now request you to be my teacher and guide. I only wish that you will explain and teach me.
The old doctor replied:
If you can serve me as an attendant for forty-eight years, then I will teach you the medical techniques.
At that time, the skilled doctor accepted his instruction:
I will do as you say, I will do as you say. I will serve as your attendant to the best of my ability.
At that time, the old doctor then took the visiting doctor to see the king together.
At that time, the visiting doctor explained various medical prescriptions and other skills to the king:
'Great king, you should know that you should skillfully distinguish, this Dharma is like this, which can be used to govern the country;
this Dharma is like this, which can be used to cure illnesses.'

At that time, when the king heard these words, he then knew that the old doctor was foolish and ignorant, and immediately drove him out of the country, and then he doubled his respect for the guest doctor.
At that time, the guest doctor thought like this:
'The time has come to teach the king.
' He then said to the king:
'If the great king truly loves me, he should make one request.'
The king immediately replied:
'From this right arm and the rest of my body, I will give you everything you seek, as you wish.'
The guest doctor said:
'Although the king has granted me all his body parts, I dare not ask for much.
What I seek now is for the king to proclaim an order throughout the country, from this day forth, that no one should take the old doctor's milk medicine again.
Why is this?
Because this medicine is poisonous and harmful, causing much injury.
If anyone still takes it, their head will be cut off.
After the milk medicine is discontinued, there will never again be anyone who dies an untimely death, and they will always dwell in peace and happiness. Therefore, I seek this wish.'
At that time, the king replied:
'What you seek is indeed not enough to be mentioned.'
He then issued an order:
'In the entire country, no one is allowed to use milk as medicine for the sick. If anyone uses it as medicine, their head will be cut off.'

At that time, the visiting doctor combined various flavors with many medicines, such as pungent, bitter, salty, sweet, sour, and so on, to treat various illnesses, and there was none that was not cured.
After some time, the king fell ill again and ordered the doctor:
'I am now gravely ill, suffering and about to die. What treatment should I use?'
The doctor examined the king's illness and prescribed milk medicine. He then said to the king:
'According to your illness, you should take milk.
The milk medicine I previously prohibited was a great lie.
If you take it now, it can best cure the illness. Your current fever is precisely curable by milk.'
At that time, the king said to the doctor:
'Are you now delirious?
Or do you have a fever?
To say that taking milk can cure this illness,
when you previously said it was poisonous, how can you take it now?
Do you want to deceive me?
The previous doctor praised it, but you said it was poisonous, causing me to expel him.
Now you say it is good and can best cure the illness.
According to your words, my original doctor must be superior to you.'
At that time, the visiting doctor again said to the king:
'Your Majesty should not speak like this. It is like an insect eating wood, and by chance forming a character. This insect does not know whether it is a character or not;
A wise person seeing it would never exclaim that the insect understands characters, nor would they be astonished.

How is milk also called nectar?

If it is a cow that does not eat brewer's grains, smooth grass, or barley chaff, and if its calf is well-behaved, the place where it is grazed is not on high plains, nor is it in low wet areas, it drinks clear water, is not allowed to run around, is not with a herd of bulls, and its feeding and resting are appropriate,

At that time, the great king, having heard these words, praised the great physician, saying:
